review.title: Relative Entailment Among Probabilistic Implications
review.abstract: We study a natural variant of the implicational fragment of propositional logic. Its formulas are pairs of conjunctions of positive literals, related together by an implicational-like connective; the semantics of this sort of implication is defined in terms of a threshold on a conditional probability of the consequent, given the antecedent: we are dealing with what the data analysis community calls confidence of partial implications or association rules. Existing studies of redundancy among these partial implications have characterized so far only entailment from one premise and entailment from two premises. Here, we provide an alternative view of this entailment in terms of linear programming duality. This view allows us to characterize exactly the cases of entailment from arbitrary numbers of premises, to obtain decision algorithms of better complexity, and to prove that the confidence threshold is, actually, intrinsic to each set of premises and antecedent of the conclusion.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 150 1.04 826v 1 [cs.L O] 20 JaWe examine a natural variant of the implicit fragment of propositional logic. Their formulas are conjunction pairs of positive literals linked by an implicit, connective relationship; the semantics of this kind of implication is defined as a threshold based on a conditional probability of the consecutive: we are dealing here with what the data analysis community calls trust in partial implications or rules of association. Existing studies of redundancy among these partial implications so far characterize only the implication from one premise and the implication from two premises. Here, we offer an alternative view of this implication in the sense of linear programming duality. This perspective allows us to characterize precisely the cases of implication from an arbitrary number of premises in order to obtain decision algorithms of better complexity and to prove that the rigid threshold of each conclusion is indeed inconsequential.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The question of how to represent human knowledge in a way that is very useful for application has been present in research for decades. Often, knowledge representation is necessary in a context of incomplete information, where inductive processes are additionally necessary. Thus, there are two facets that are common to a large number of works in knowledge representation, especially in the contexts of inductive inferencing, machine learning, or data analysis, both of which are understood as logical and probable concepts. There are a variety of approaches that enhance their expressivity and usefulness, but pay high prices in terms of computer difficulties.
